passage_text: 1 All-porcelain crowns are the most delicate, most lifelike and most expensive and the cost reflects this. 2  These types of crowns cost from $800 to over $3,000. 3  Insurance copays for all-porcelain crowns range from $530 – $1,875, with an average out of pocket cost of $950 per crown. 1 Costs run from $500 to $1,500 or more per tooth. 2  Patients with insurance generally had copays of $280 to $1,000 per crown with an average payment of $620. 3  Those without coverage paid $875 to $1,400 per tooth with an average cost of nearly $1,100.

1 CostHelper readers without insurance report paying $830-$2,465 for a metal crown, at an average cost of $1,353. 2  CostHelper readers with insurance report out-of-pocket expenses of $519-$1,140, for an average payment of $882. 1 If a large area of tooth is missing because of decay or damage, there may be an additional charge of $150-$250 or more to build up the tooth (although some dentists include this cost in their quoted price for a crown).

1 Metal crowns of gold alloy (called high noble metal) or of base metal alloys (non-noble) can cost $600-$2,500 or more per tooth. 2  CostHelper readers without insurance report paying $830-$2,465 for a metal crown, at an average cost of $1,353. 1 If a large area of tooth is missing because of decay or damage, there may be an additional charge of $150-$250 or more to build up the tooth (although some dentists include this cost in their quoted price for a crown).

1 All-porcelain crowns require a higher level of skill and take more time to install than metal or porcelain-fused-to-metal crowns, and can cost $800-$3,000 or more per tooth. 2  CostHelper readers without insurance report paying $860-$3,000, at an average cost of $1,430. 1 If a large area of tooth is missing because of decay or damage, there may be an additional charge of $150-$250 or more to build up the tooth (although some dentists include this cost in their quoted price for a crown).

Cost of molar crown depends on type of crown you go for. cost also varies from dentist to dentist and place to place. For molars, porcelain fused to metal or metallic dental crowns can be given to the patient. Porcelain fused to metal dental crown PFM dental crown will cost you $600-$900. cost of metallic dental crown depends on extent of noble metal. Cost of molar extraction will vary according to the procedure which is used for tooth extraction. If simple tooth extraction is done for it, then it will cost you around $100-$150. if surgical tooth extraction is done, then it will cost you $250-$300.

The prices for dental crowns range from $500 to $2,500 per crown and are dependent upon the materials used, location of tooth and geographic location. The average cost of a crown is $825, with or without dental insurance coverage. The cheapest cost of a dental crown is $500 for a simple metal crown. 1 Costs run from $500 to $1,500 or more per tooth. 2  Patients with insurance generally had copays of $280 to $1,000 per crown with an average payment of $620. 3  Those without coverage paid $875 to $1,400 per tooth with an average cost of nearly $1,100.

1 Metal crowns made of gold alloy or of base-metal alloys and generally cost $600 to $2,500 per tooth depending on the metal and the size of the tooth. 2  People with insurance typically paid $520 – $1,140 out of pocket with an average of $882 per crown. 1 Costs run from $500 to $1,500 or more per tooth. 2  Patients with insurance generally had copays of $280 to $1,000 per crown with an average payment of $620. 3  Those without coverage paid $875 to $1,400 per tooth with an average cost of nearly $1,100.

The cost of the average traditional molar crown, not those used for cosmetic dentistry or reconstruction, would cost about $400 per tooth. There are gold crowns that are slightly more expensive, at about $550 and the porcelain-fused type which is roughly the same price. Cost of molar extraction will vary according to the procedure which is used for tooth extraction. If simple tooth extraction is done for it, then it will cost you around $100-$150. if surgical tooth extraction is done, then it will cost you $250-$300.

1 Porcelain-fused-to-metal crowns can cost $500-$1,500 or more per tooth. 2  For example, CostHelper readers without insurance coverage report paying $875-$1,400 for porcelain-fused-to-metal crowns, at an average cost of $1,093. 1 If a large area of tooth is missing because of decay or damage, there may be an additional charge of $150-$250 or more to build up the tooth (although some dentists include this cost in their quoted price for a crown).
